George \"Cookie\" Phillips wrote:
> As Deathifier pointed out, much of the programming should be ANSI C or C++ ... more compatable, that way (for linux ports, etc)..
> 
> But there should be a chosen compiler for the 'official release', whatever that may be.
> 

There are two good C++ compilers (actually I haven't tried the borland
one but I assume it's good) that I know of.  Borland C++ BUILDER I just
downloaded off the borland site, and DJGPP is what I learned with and
used a couple years ago when I used to do more coding, and wrote a
couple of fairly simple games.  I never did get the windows port of that
working though, all dos stuff, but I assume this has improved since
then.  The one advantage of DGJPP that I can see is if someone wanted to
port it to linux ever it would probably be fairly trivial since most
linux distributions use the GNU C compiler for the default (DJGPP is the
dos port of the GNG C compiler). 


> I'm not a pro coder... i'm not even really a hobbyist anymore.. but I've got some knowledge that may prove useful.

heh,  basically same here.  I'de sure enjoy working on something though,
haven't had anything to code in a long time, and none of my friends know
anything about it. 
 
> I e-mailed DPH privately, thinking he was gonna be lead programmer.. Obviously, this is no longer the case. 

Uh,  anyone wanna volenteer to co-ordinate things?  Once things get
going we should probably start a new mailing list so we don't drive
people insane on this one if they aren't interested.

> ... so, anyone ever coded a group project before? (and, should this be opensource or closed source?)

I vote open source.  closest thing to a group project I've done are
webpages ( cause like I said, my friends don't know much about coding)


Oh yea,  and thanks Tom for all the info; it should simplify things a
lot.
